resources.string: Mean (M) and standard deviation (SD)\nEnter your data e.g.: 2.5;23;5.06 ...
Cohen\'s d (effect size)\nEnter your data as: M1; SD1; M2; SD2
r (effect size)\nEnter your data as: Z; N1; N2
η2 (effect size)\nEnter your data as: t; N1; N2
Long click on "C" clears the display

Psy-Tool is a free (no ads) “tool box” app useful in everyday psychological assessment. Simple stopwatch and timer with big buttons, a calculator with an option of basic statistics estimation (arithmetic mean, standard deviation, effect size), and a standard scales interpretation/converter helper is a tiny but handy tool in your pocket, ready to use.
This is the first, far from flawless, version of the app. Hence, if you have any comments regarding its design, functions or anything else, just send me a message (lesniak@neurony.org). I will fix what I can in order to make you a happy user.
Marcin Lesniak and Neurony.org

Credits
Sound effects used in this app come from the site: www.freesfx.co.uk

Statistical functions (activated by STAT button) include:

1. Calculation of arithmetic mean (M) and standard deviation (SD)
- enter your data (min. 5 numbers) separated by “;”

2. Calculation of Cohen’s d (effect size)
- enter your data as: M of group 1 ; SD of group 1 ; M of group 2 ; SD of group 2
- the program calculates d based on the formula: (M2 – M1)/sqrt((SD2^2 + SD1^2)/2) 
- interpretation: >0.2- small effect, >0.5- moderate effect, >0.8- large effect

3. Calculation of r coefficient (effect size for non-parametric statistics- Wilcoxon, Mann-Whitney)
- enter your data as: Z value ; number of subjects in group 1 ; number of subjects in group 2
- the program calculates r based on the formula: Z/sqrt(N1+N2)
- interpretation: >0.1- small effect, >0.3- moderate effect, >0.5- large effect

4. Calculation of η2 coefficient (effect size for t statistic for independent groups)
- enter your data as: t value ; number of subjects in group 1 ; number of subjects in group 2
- the program calculates eta2 based on the formula: t/sqrt(t) + (N1+N2-2)
- interpretation: >0.01- small effect, >0.06- moderate effect, >0.14- large effect

Standard scales:

SD- standard deviation
z- standard score (mean= 0; standard deviation= 1)
P- percentiles (mean= 50)
T- transformed scores (mean= 50; standard deviation= 10)
Sten- standard tens score (mean= 5.5; standard deviation= 2)
Stanine- standard nine score (mean= 5; standard deviation= 2)
IQ- Wechsler intelligence quotient (mean= 100; standard deviation= 15)
SS- scaled score (mean= 10; standard deviation= 3)

Interpretation:
According to Lezak M., Howieson D., Bigler E., Tranel D. (2012). Neuropsychological Assessment. 5th Ed. Oxford: Oxford University Press:
Very superior: +2.0 and above
Superior: +1.3 to 2.0
High average: +0.6 to 1.3
Average: ±0.6
Low average: -0.6 to -1.3
Borderline: -1.3 to -2.0
Retarded: -2.0 and below

According to Wanlass R. (2012). The Neuropsychology Toolkit. NY: Springer:
Exceptional: above 3.0
Very superior: 2.0 to 3.0
Superior: 1.0 to 2.0
High average: 0.67 to 1.0 
Average: 0.67 to -0.66 
Low average: -0.67 to 1.0 
Mild deficit: -1.0 to -2.0 
Moderate deficit: -2.0 to -3.0 
Severe deficit: below -3.0

Scores ranging from low average through high average are considered to be within normal limits
